head.title: HYUNDAI BACKS AWAY FROM BREAKUP PLAN

hedline.hl1: HYUNDAI BACKS AWAY FROM BREAKUP PLAN

abstract.p: Hyundai Group, emboldened by its new partnership with DaimlerChrysler to capture 97 percent of South Korea's car market, backs away from plans to split off its flagship car-making subsidiary (S)

block.p: Emboldened by its new partnership with DaimlerChrysler to capture 97 percent of South Korea's car market, the Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, backed away from plans to split off its flagship car-making subsidiary. Following concerns of a cash shortage last month, Hyundai had been under increased government pressure to shed its vast lineup of subsidiaries. Earlier this week, Chung Ju Yung, the founder of the Hyundai Group, increased his stake in the automaker to 9.1 percent from 6.9 percent. The increased stake by the former honorary chairman of Hyundai has raised concerns that he will continue to exercise significant power over the company.

Earlier this week, Chung Ju Yung, the founder of the Hyundai Group, increased his stake in the automaker to 9.1 percent from 6.9 percent. The increased stake by the former honorary chairman of Hyundai has raised concerns that he will continue to exercise significant power over the company.
